Genus: Billbergia are evergreen, rosette-forming perennials with linear or strap-shaped leaves and panicles or racemes of tubular flowers, usually with colourful bracts
Cultivation: Grow outdoors as an epiphyte or in humus-rich, sharply drained soil in frost-free location. Under glass grow as an epiphyte or in epiphytic bromeliad compost in bright indirect light. Keep the centre funnel filled with fresh water
Propagation: Propagate by seed or by removing offsets
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Sub-tropical Patio & Container Plants

Genus: Betula can be deciduous trees or shrubs, usually colouring well in autumn and often with striking white, pink, or peeling brown bark; separate male and female catkins open before or with the leaves in spring
Aspect: North-facing or South-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Will grow in a wide range of situations. Effective when planted in small groups or as a multi-stemmed specimen
Propagation: Propagate by seed, softwood cuttings or grafting
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Wildlife Gardens
Pests: Sawflies, aphids and leaf- mining sawflies may be a problem
Diseases: A rust and a leaf spot may be a problem

Genus: Betula can be deciduous trees or shrubs, usually colouring well in autumn and often with striking white, pink, or peeling brown bark; separate male and female catkins open before or with the leaves in spring
Aspect: East-facing or South-facing or North-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Suitable as isolated specimen or in small groups. Has attractive peeling bark
Propagation: Propagate by seed, softwood cuttings or grafting
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wildlife Gardens Wildflower meadow
Pests: Sawflies, aphids and leaf- mining sawflies may be a problem
Diseases: A rust and a leaf spot may be a problem

Genus: Blechnum are mostly evergreen ferns with erect or creeping rhizomes and simply pinnate, leathery fronds, the fertile ones usually erect, the sterile often spreading
Cultivation: Grow in moist but free draining soil in partial shade.
Propagation: Propagate by division or spores
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs Low Maintenance Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden

Genus: Betula can be deciduous trees or shrubs, usually colouring well in autumn and often with striking white, pink, or peeling brown bark; separate male and female catkins open before or with the leaves in spring
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or East-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Will grow in a wide range of situations
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings or grafting
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Hedging & Screens Low Maintenance Architectural Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: Birch borers, sawflies, aphids and leaf- mining sawflies may be a problem
Diseases: Susceptible to honey fungus and powdery mildew. A rust and a leaf spot may also be a problem

Genus: Bletilla are deciduous terrestrial perennial orchids with tuber-like pseudobulbs, ribbed, linear to lance-shaped leaves, and erect racemes of bell-shaped flowers
Aspect: West-facing or South-facing or North-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Under glass, grow in loamed-based potting compost (JI No.2) with added leaf mould, in bright filtered or bright indirect light. In summer water freely, applying a quarter strength balanced liquid fertiliser at every third watering. Keep dry in winter
Propagation: Divide in early spring, when plant is large enough
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Patio & Container Plants
Pests: Glasshouse red spider mite, aphids, glasshouse whitefly and mealybugs may be troublesome

Genus: Bomarea are tuberous, deciduous twining perennials with simple, lance-shaped leaves and terminal umbels or racemes of tubular or narrowly bell-shaped flowers
Cultivation: Grow under glass in well-drained compost in good light but with shade from the hottest sun. Will need support and can stand outside in summer in a sunny position
Propagation: Propagate by seed, or by division in late winter or early spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Patio & Container Plants Mediterranean Climate Plants
Pruning: Cut back dead growth and flowered stems to ground level in winter
Pests: May be affected by glasshouse red spider mite, glasshouse whitefly and aphids

Genus: Blechnum are mostly evergreen ferns with erect or creeping rhizomes and simply pinnate, leathery fronds, the fertile ones usually erect, the sterile often spreading
Cultivation: Best grown under glass in frost-free conditions in a neutral to acid loam compost with bright filtered or indirect light, a humid atmosphere and good ventilation. Outdoors, for warmer UK counties only, grow in a very sheltered position in moist, humus-rich neutral to acid soil in full to part shade
Propagation: Propagate by spores in summer or propagate by division but may take some time to re-establish
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Patio & Container Plants Sub-tropical
Pruning: Tidy if necessary, removing older fronds

Genus: Blechnum are mostly evergreen ferns with erect or creeping rhizomes and simply pinnate, leathery fronds, the fertile ones usually erect, the sterile often spreading
Cultivation: Easy to grow in most cool, moist, shaded sites
Propagation: Propagate by sowing spores (may not come true) in mid to late summer or by division in spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Banks and Slopes Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden Patio & Container Plants
Pruning: Dead or damaged fronds may be removed as necessary

Genus: Blechnum are mostly evergreen ferns with erect or creeping rhizomes and simply pinnate, leathery fronds, the fertile ones usually erect, the sterile often spreading
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or East-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Easy to grow in most cool, moist, shaded sites
Propagation: Propagate by sowing spores (may not come true) in mid to late summer or by division in spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs
Pruning: Dead or damaged fronds may be removed as necessary

Genus: Bouteloua can be annuals, rhizomatous or stoloniferous perennial grasses, with linear leaves and erect stems bearing distinctive flattened, horizontal flowering spikes
Cultivation: Grow in a sharply drained soil soil in full sun. Avoid winter wet
Propagation: Propagate by seed in containers in a cold frame in spring. Alternatively divide clumps from mid-spring to early summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal Patio & Container Plants
Pruning: Cut back overwintered material in early spring, just before new growth begins

Genus: Brahea is a genus of palms, endemic to Mexico and Central America. Also called hesper palms, they all have large, fan-shaped leaves.
Cultivation: In frost-prone areas, grow young specimens in full light as houseplants or under glass at 5-15°C in loam-based potting compost such as John Innes No. 2, water moderately and apply a balanced liquid fertilizer monthly while in growth, water sparingly in winter, and pot on or top-dress in spring - for more advice, see palm cultivation indoors; in frost-free areas, grow in well-drained soil in full sun; will tolerate poor, dry soil, and will survive short periods at 0°C - for more advice, see palm cultivation outdoors
Propagation: Sow seed at 23-27°C in spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Drought Resistant Architectural City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal Sub-tropical Patio & Container Plants
Pests: May be affected by glasshouse red spider mite and scale insects

Genus: Briza can be annual or perennial grasses forming dense tufts of linear leaves, with long-lasting, open panicles of nodding spikelets on slender branches; useful for dried flower arrangement
Cultivation: Easy to grow in most well-drained soils in a sunny position
Propagation: Propagate by seed
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Cut Flowers City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden
Pruning: None required but flowerheads can be cut back in late summer to encourage new growth

Genus: Brimeura are bulbous perennials with linear leaves in a basal tuft, and racemes of narrowly bell-shaped blue flowers in spring
Aspect: North-facing or East-facing or South-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Grow in well-drained, humus-rich soil and plant 5cm deep in autumn
Propagation: Propagate by seed, sown in containers in a cold frame when ripe or by division of clumps in summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden Rock Garden

Genus: Brunnera are rhizomatous herbaceous perennials with large, ovate or heart-shaped basal leaves and sprays of small bright blue flowers in spring
Cultivation: Best grown in moderately fertile, humus-rich soil that is moist but well-drained. A cool site in partial shade or shade is preferred
Propagation: Propagate by division in early spring or take root cuttings in winter
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Banks and Slopes Flower borders and beds Low Maintenance Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs Ground Cover Cottage & Informal Garden City & Courtyard Gardens

Genus: Buddleja can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, occasionally trees or scrambling climbers with simple leaves and panicles of small, tubular fragrant flowers
Cultivation: Grow in fertile, well-drained soil in full sun
Propagation: Root semi-ripe cuttings in summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Hedging & Screens Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: Prone to aphids, capsid bug, caterpillars and earwigs. Leaf and bud eelworm, figwort weevil and mullein moth are occasionally troublesome
Diseases: Occasional problems with fungal leaf spot, honey fungus and a virus

Genus: Buddleja can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, occasionally trees or scrambling climbers with simple leaves and panicles of small, tubular fragrant flowers
Cultivation: Performs best when grown in a sunny, sheltered, well-drained situation
Propagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Low Maintenance Drought Resistant Cottage & Informal Garden Wildlife Gardens
Pests: Can get capsid bug, caterpillars, leaf and bud eelworms, figwort weevil, aphids and glasshouse red spider mite

Genus: Buddleja can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, occasionally trees or scrambling climbers with simple leaves and panicles of small, tubular fragrant flowers
Cultivation: Grow in well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade
Propagation: Propagate semi-ripe cuttings in summer or hardwood cuttings in autumn
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Wall-side Borders Drought Resistant City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: May be attacked by capsid bug, caterpillars and glasshouse red spider mite

Genus: Buddleja can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, occasionally trees or scrambling climbers with simple leaves and panicles of small, tubular fragrant flowers
Cultivation: Buddleja perform best when grown in a sunny, well-drained situation
Propagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings.
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Drought Resistant Low Maintenance Coastal Cottage & Informal Garden Wildlife Gardens
Pests: Can get capsid bug, caterpillars, leaf and bud eelworms, aphids and glasshouse red spider mite

Genus: Buddleja can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, occasionally trees or scrambling climbers with simple leaves and panicles of small, tubular fragrant flowers
Cultivation: Under glass grow in loam-based potting compost in full light with good ventilation. Water freely in summer and keep just moist in winter. Can be grown outdoors in a sheltered site
Propagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings in summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Coastal City & Courtyard Gardens Wildlife Gardens
Pests: May be attacked by glasshouse whitefly and glasshouse red spider mite

Genus: Broussonetia are deciduous trees and shrubs with alternate leaves, and male and female flowers borne on separate plants
Cultivation: Will only survive in mild areas, but will grow in almost any well-drained soil, in full sun with shelter from wind. Where summers are hot enough to ripen wood, will mature as a tree, otherwise remains shrubby
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown in autumn, or by semi-ripe or hardwood cuttings, or by removing suckers
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Cottage & Informal Garden
Diseases: Susceptible to canker and leaf spot

Genus: Buddleja can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, occasionally trees or scrambling climbers with simple leaves and panicles of small, tubular fragrant flowers
Cultivation: Buddleja perform best when grown in a sunny, well-drained situation
Propagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Wall-side Borders Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: Foliage may be damaged by capsid bug and caterpillars

Genus: Buddleja can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, occasionally trees or scrambling climbers with simple leaves and panicles of small, tubular fragrant flowers
Cultivation: Requires full sun, good drainage and shelter, for example by a wall, as not totally hardy
Propagation: Propagate by semi-ripe cuttings in summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wall-side Borders City & Courtyard Gardens Mediterranean Climate Plants
Pruning: May be pruned hard back in spring as flowers on current season's growth

Genus: Bulbinella can be evergreen or deciduous, clump-forming perennials with narrow, somewhat fleshy leaves in a rosette, and many small, star-shaped, usually yellow or white flowers in a dense raceme held well above the leaves
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained, neutral to acid soil in full sun or partial shade. Mulch with leaf mould in winter. Can also be grown in an alpine house in containers of equal parts loam, leaf mould and sharp sand
Propagation: Propagate by seed in a cold frame as soon as ripe or propagate by division in autumn
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Wall-side Borders City & Courtyard Gardens Rock Garden Coastal Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: Under glass, glasshouse whitefly, aphids and glasshouse red spider mite may be problematic

Genus: Butomus are submerged rhizomatous perennials with narrowly strap-shaped leaves and 6-petalled pink flowers held in umbels well above water level
Cultivation: Grow in fertile mud at pond margins or in water up to 25cm deep, in full sun
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown as soon as ripe or by rhizome division in spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wildlife Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden

Genus: Bupleurum may be annuals, perennials or evergreen shrubs; the leaves are simple, the tiny yellow or green flowers are borne in a cluster usually subtended by petal-like green to yellow bracts
Cultivation: Grow in any well-drained soil in a warm sheltered site with full sun
Propagation: Propagate by seed in containers in a cold frame in spring; root semi-ripe cuttings in summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Banks and Slopes Cut Flowers Wall-side Borders City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal Cottage & Informal Garden

Genus: Buxus can be evergreen shrubs or small trees, with simple, leathery, opposite leaves and clusters of small, pale yellow flowers followed by pale green to brown fruits
Hardiness: Ingestion may cause stomach upset, contact may irritate the skin. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
Cultivation: Grow in well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade. See also box problems
Propagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Hedging & Screens City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: May be attacked by box sucker and glasshouse red spider mite

Genus: Calanthe are evergreen, semi-evergreen or deciduous orchids that may be terrestrial or epiphytic. They have corm-like pseudobulbs and basal clusters of pleated leaves. Loose racemes of showy flowers with 3-lobed lips may appear, on erect stems, in spring, summer or winter
Cultivation: Under glass grow in terrestrial orchid compost in bright, filtered light with high humidity. Outdoors grow in coarse, well-drained, humus-rich soil in a sheltered site in partial shade
Propagation: Propagation
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Patio & Container Plants City & Courtyard Gardens
Pests: Under glass prone to mealybugs, orchid scale insect, glasshouse red spider mite and aphids; outdoors protect from slugs and snails

Genus: Buxus can be evergreen shrubs or small trees, with simple, leathery, opposite leaves and clusters of small, pale yellow flowers followed by pale green to brown fruits
Hardiness: Ingestion may cause stomach upset, contact may irritate the skin. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
Aspect: East-facing or South-facing or North-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Grows best in well-drained soil in partial shade; can be scorched by sun and strong winds. Susceptible to a number of box problems
Propagation: Propagate from semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Garden Edging Hedging & Screens Low Maintenance Banks and Slopes Drought Resistant Ground Cover Patio & Container Plants Mediterranean Climate Plants
Pests: Can get box sucker, mussel scale and box red spider mite
Diseases: Susceptible to a leaf spot and box blight

Genus: Calamintha are pleasantly aromatic perennials with ovate leaves and loose clusters of small, 2-lipped flowers in summer and autumn in the axils of the upper leaves
PlantRange: Europe, NW Africa, N Turkey, Caucasus, Ukraine
Cultivation: Prefers a well-drained soil and flowers best when grown in a warm, open position in full sun
Propagation: Propagate by seed or by division
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Ground Cover Low Maintenance Drought Resistant City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden Gravel Garden
Diseases: May be prone to powdery mildews

Genus: Callicarpa can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs, with simple, opposite leaves and tiny white pink or purple flowers in axillary clusters, followed by small, usually colourful fruits. Several shrubs grown together ensures pollination for successful fruiting
Cultivation: Grow in fertile, well-drained soil in sun or partial shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed in autumn or spring or propagate by softwood cuttings in spring or semi-ripe cuttings in summer with bottom heat
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Cut Flowers Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden

Genus: Callistemon are evergreen shrubs with aromatic, linear to lance-shaped leaves and bottlebrush-like spikes of flowers in which the long colourful stamens are prominent
Cultivation: Grow in full sun in moderately fertile, freely-draining but moisture-retentive neutral or acidic soil; under glass grow in loam-based compost (John Innes No. 2)
Propagation: Propagate by seed, sown onto moist compost at 16-18°C, in spring, or by heeled semi-ripe cuttings of lateral shoots in late summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Wall-side Borders Hedging & Screens Coastal City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden Mediterranean Climate Plants
Pruning: Pruning group 1 (little or no pruning of trees and shrubs)
Pests: May be affected by glasshouse red spider mite, mealybugs, and scale insects, especially under glass

Genus: Callistemon are evergreen shrubs with aromatic, linear to lance-shaped leaves and bottlebrush-like spikes of flowers in which the long colourful stamens are prominent
Cultivation: Grow in a sheltered position in full sun with a moist but well-drained soil
Propagation: Propagate by seed or from semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wall-side Borders City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal
Pests: Can get glasshouse red spider mite, mealybugs and scale insects under glass

Genus: Callistemon are evergreen shrubs with aromatic, linear to lance-shaped leaves and bottlebrush-like spikes of flowers in which the long colourful stamens are prominent
Cultivation: Grow in full sun in a moist but well-drained acid or neutral soil
Propagation: Propagate by seed, surface sown onto moist compost in spring, or from semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wall-side Borders City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal Mediterranean Climate Plants

Genus: Calluna are low-growing or dwarf evergreen shrubs with stems clothed in tiny overlapping leaves, and terminal, spike-like racemes of small, 4-petalled flowers with coloured calyces
Cultivation: Grow in well-drained acidic soil in full sun
Propagation: Propagate by seed in spring, or propagate by softwood cuttings, division or layering in summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Rock Garden Coastal Wildlife Gardens
Pruning: Pruning group 10. Shear off old flowering stems after flowering
Diseases: May be subject to fungal diseases and root diseases, especially in warmer locations

Genus: Calceolaria can be annuals, biennials, perennials or shrubs, with opposite leaves or basal rosettes, and solitary or clustered, slipper-like yellow, red or purple flowers
Cultivation: Grow as summer bedding or plant in a container, flowers best in cool, moist conditions, likes acid soil or compost in sun or partial shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed or softwood cuttings taken in late summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Patio & Container Plants City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden

Genus: Calocedrus are evergreen trees with tiny, scale-like leaves arranged in ranks on the shoots, forming flattened sprays of foliage, with small ovoid cones
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grows well in any well-drained soil. Good as specimen tree
Propagation: Propagate by seed or semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Architectural

Genus: Callistemon are evergreen shrubs with aromatic, linear to lance-shaped leaves and bottlebrush-like spikes of flowers in which the long colourful stamens are prominent
Cultivation: Grow in a sheltered position in full sun with a moist but well-drained soil
Propagation: Propagate by seed or from semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wall-side Borders Patio & Container Plants Mediterranean Climate Plants City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal
Pests: Can get glasshouse red spider mite, mealybugs and scale insects under glass

Genus: Callistemon are evergreen shrubs with aromatic, linear to lance-shaped leaves and bottlebrush-like spikes of flowers in which the long colourful stamens are prominent
Cultivation: Grow in a frost-free, sheltered position in full sun with a moist but well-drained soil. Ideal for an unheated, but frost-free conservatory or greenhouse. If planting in a container, use a well-drained peat-free mix with 20% by volume of horticultural grit added
Propagation: Propagate by seed or from semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Coastal City & Courtyard Gardens Gravel Garden Mediterranean Climate Plants Sub-tropical
Pests: May be susceptible to glasshouse red spider mite, mealybugs and scale insects under glass

Genus: Calycanthus are deciduous shrubs with simple, aromatic leaves and solitary, fragrant flowers in summer
Aspect: North-facing or South-facing or East-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Prefers moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil in partial shade where it grows taller, but tolerates a wide range of soil conditions and some sun. Shelter from cold, drying winds. Autumn colour is better in its native habitat.
Propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Wall-side Borders Architectural City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden Wildlife Gardens
Pruning: Prune immediately after flowering to shape and maintain size. Remove root suckers promptly. Tends to form colonies in the wild.

Genus: Calycanthus are deciduous shrubs with simple, aromatic leaves and solitary, fragrant flowers in summer
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Good for woodland or stream side positions
Propagation: Propagate by seed or softwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Low Maintenance Architectural Cottage & Informal Garden

Genus: Camassia are bulbous perennials with narrow, channelled leaves and erect racemes of star-shaped violet-blue or creamy-white flowers in early summer
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained, humus-rich, fertile soil. Intolerant of waterlogging and may need some protection from frosts in colder areas
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame as soon as seed is ripe. Remove offsets when dormant in winter
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Banks and Slopes Flower borders and beds Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs Cottage & Informal Garden Wildflower meadow

Genus: Camellia are evergreen shrubs with simple, ovate, glossy, leathery leaves and showy flowers with solitary or clustered flowers early in the year
Cultivation: Suitable for woodland and acidic soils. Position in a site sheltered from cold, dry winds and early morning sun as buds and flowers may be damaged by cold winds and late frosts see camellia cultivation
Propagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Flower borders and beds Wall-side Borders Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: May be attacked by aphids, scale insects and vine weevil
Diseases: May be affected by honey fungus, phytophthora root rot, camellia gall, camellia leaf blight, camellia yellow mottle virus and flowers may be infected by camellia petal blight

Genus: Caltha are rhizomatous herbaceous perennials with simple, usually heart-shaped leaves and cup-shaped yellow or white flowers in early spring
Cultivation: Grow in an open site in rich boggy soil at the water's edge in full sun
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown as soon as ripe or by division in late summer or early spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Low Maintenance Wildlife Gardens
Diseases: Powdery mildews may be a problem

Genus: Camassia are bulbous perennials with narrow, channelled leaves and erect racemes of star-shaped violet-blue or creamy-white flowers in early summer
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained, deep, humus-rich, fertile soil. Intolerant of waterlogging and may need some protection from frosts in colder areas. Very good for naturalising in meadows
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame as soon as seed is ripe. Remove offsets when dormant in winter- see bulb propagation
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Banks and Slopes Cut Flowers Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs Cottage & Informal Garden Wildflower meadow
Pruning: Cut back faded flower spike unless collecting seed

Genus: Camellia are evergreen shrubs with simple, ovate, glossy, leathery leaves and showy flowers with solitary or clustered flowers early in the year
Cultivation: Suitable for woodland and acidic soils. Position in a site sheltered from cold, dry winds and early morning sun as buds and flowers may be damaged by cold winds and late frosts see camellia cultivation
Propagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wall-side Borders Flower borders and beds Low Maintenance Cottage & Informal Garden Patio & Container Plants City & Courtyard Gardens
Pests: May be attacked by aphids, scale insects and vine weevil
Diseases: May be affected by honey fungus, phytophthora root rot, camellia gall, camellia leaf blight, camellia yellow mottle virus and flowers may be infected by camellia petal blight

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or East-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Ideal for rock gardens or containers. Will not tolerate wet winters
Propagation: Propagate by seed or softwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Cottage & Informal Garden Gravel Garden Patio & Container Plants City & Courtyard Gardens Rock Garden
Pests: May be damaged by slugs and snails
Diseases: May be infected by powdery mildews and a leaf spot

Genus: Camellia are evergreen shrubs with simple, ovate, glossy, leathery leaves and showy flowers with solitary or clustered flowers early in the year
Aspect: North-facing or South-facing or West-facing or ,
Cultivation: Choose a shady, sheltered site with acid soil that is fertile, moist, but well-drained. Plant shallowly, and mulch with bark or leaf mould. Buds and flowers should be protected from cold dry winds. Don't allow to dry out. Fertilise mid-spring and early summer.
Propagation: Propagate by seed, soak seed prior to sowing, sow when ripe under glass. Can also be propogated via hardwood and semi-hardwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Low Maintenance Wall-side Borders Architectural City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden
Pruning: Requires little pruning. Removal of damaged, dead, or diseased branches is best done after flowering.
Pests: May be susceptible to aphids, scale insects and vine weevil
Diseases: May be susceptible to other Camellia diseases, such as Camellia petal blight

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Ideal for rock gardens or containers. Will not tolerate wet winters
Propagation: Propagate by seed or by basal cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: City & Courtyard Gardens Gravel Garden Patio & Container Plants Rock Garden Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: May be damaged by slugs and snails
Diseases: May be infected by powdery mildews and a leaf spot

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: North-facing or West-facing or South-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Prefers moist but well-drained soil in a sunny position. Ideal for rock gardens, borders, or containers
Propagation: Propagate by seed or softwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Ground Cover Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs Garden Edging City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden Gravel Garden Patio & Container Plants Rock Garden
Pests: May be damaged by slugs and snails
Diseases: May be affected by powdery mildews

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Plant in moderately fertile, well-drained soil in a sunny position
Propagation: Propagate by seed in winter or spring in a cold frame
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden City & Courtyard Gardens Patio & Container Plants Rock Garden
Pests: Slugs and snails may be problematic

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: North-facing or West-facing or South-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Requires a fertile, moist but well-drained, neutral to alkaline soil in sun or partial shade. The delicate flower colour is best preserved in partial shade. The plants may require staking in exposed positions
Propagation: Propagate by seed in containers in a cold frame in spring. The plants will self seed, if allowed to do so and produce plants with some colour variation. Divide clumps in spring or early autumn. Take stem-tip cuttings from new growth after flowering
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden
Pruning: Cut back after flowering to prevent self-seeding and to encourage a second flush of flowers
Diseases: Powdery mildews and a rust may be problematic

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Cultivation: Grow in gritty, well-drained soil in a trough or in a deep pot in an alpine house. Protect from winter wet
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown in summer as soon as ripe - seed needs light to germinate - or take basal stem cuttings, and insert into gritty compost in late spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Gravel Garden Patio & Container Plants Rock Garden
Pests: May be attacked by slugs, snails, aphids and glasshouse red spider mite
Diseases: May be subject to powdery mildews

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grows best in sun or partial shade in a moist, well drained soil
Propagation: Propagate by seed
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Banks and Slopes Flower borders and beds Low Maintenance Cottage & Informal Garden Wildlife Gardens Wildflower meadow
Pests: May be damaged by slugs and snails
Diseases: May be infected by a rust

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or West-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Any fertile, moist but well-drained soil in sun or partial shade; the delicate flower colour is best preserved in shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed in containers in a cold frame in spring. Divide in spring or early autumn. Take stem-tip cuttings from new growth after flowering

Pruning: Cut back after flowering to prevent self-seeding and to encourage a second flush of flowers
Diseases: Powdery mildew and rust may be problematic

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: North-facing or East-facing or South-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Best grown in fertile, neutral to alkaline soil that is moist but well-drained; in partial shade or sun. Needs staking in exposed sites - see staking perennials
Propagation: Propagate by division in spring or autumn or take basal cuttings in spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Underplanting of Roses and Shrubs Cut Flowers Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden
Pruning: Cut back after flowering to prevent self-seeding and to encourage a second flush of flowers

Diseases: May be infected by a rust, powdery mildews and a leaf spot

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Cultivation: Grow in gritty, moist but well-drained soil in a trough or in a pot in an alpine house. Protect from winter wet
Propagation: Propagate by taking basal stem cuttings, insert into gritty compost in late spring

Pruning: Cut back after flowering to maintain compact shape

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: West-facing or East-facing or South-facing or North-facing
Cultivation: Suitable for rock garden, sunny wall or bank.
Propagation: Propagate by seed, division or take basal cuttings

Pests: Can be damaged by slugs, snails, glasshouse red spider mite and aphids

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained soil in sun or partial shade; can be invasive as spreads by underground runners
Propagation: Propagate by division in spring or autumn

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: South-facing or West-facing or North-facing or East-facing
Cultivation: Grow in gritty, moist but sharply drained soil in full sun. Suits a scree bed trough or alpine house in loam-based potting compost (JI No.1) with plenty of grit. Ideal for sunny wall or rock crevice planting
Propagation: Propagate by seed in containers in an open cold frame in autumn. Take cuttings of new growth in early spring or summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Banks and Slopes Garden Edging City & Courtyard Gardens Cottage & Informal Garden Rock Garden Gravel Garden Patio & Container Plants
Pests: vine weevil may be a problem under glass. Vulnerable to slugs and snails

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: West-facing or East-facing or South-facing or North-facing
Cultivation: Any fertile, well-drained soil in sun or part shade. The flower colour is best in shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed in containers in a cold frame in spring. Divide in spring or autumn. Take stem-tip cuttings from new growth after flowering

Pruning: Cut back after flowering to prevent seeding and to encourage a second flush of flower

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Aspect: South-facing or North-facing or East-facing or West-facing
Cultivation: Grows best in a well-drained soil in full sun
Propagation: Propagate by seed
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Cottage & Informal Garden Gravel Garden Rock Garden City & Courtyard Gardens
Diseases: Generally trouble free but may be infected by a rust, powdery mildews and a leaf spot

Genus: Campanula may be annuals, herbaceous or evergreen perennials, with bell or star-shaped, often blue, flowers in late spring or summer
Cultivation: Grow in well-drained soil in full sun
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown in containers in a cold frame in spring. Divide in spring or autumn
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Banks and Slopes Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden Cottage & Informal Garden Gravel Garden
Pruning: Cut back after flowering to prevent seeding and to encourage a second flush of flower
Diseases: Powdery mildews and rust diseases may be problematic

Genus: Campsis are fast-growing deciduous climbers clinging by aerial roots, pinnate leaves and clusters of tubular-funnel-shaped flowers in late summer or early autumn
Cultivation: A climber that despite its exotic-looking flowers is reasonably hardy if grown against a warm, sunny wall
Propagation: Propagate by seed, layering, hardwood cuttings or root cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wall-side Borders
Pruning: Pruning campsis; pruning group 12 in late winter or early spring
Pests: Generally pest free but aphids may attack the flowers

Genus: Canarina are twining tuberous herbaceous perennials with simple leaves and one or more nodding bell-shaped flowers with 6 lobes
Cultivation: Under glass grow in loam-based potting compost in bright filtered light with good ventilation. Water freely when in growth and keep completely dry when foliage yellows in late spring. Apply a balanced liquid fertiliser monthly when in growth. Pot on when dormant
Propagation: Propagate by seed at 15-18°C in spring
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wall-side Borders Cottage & Informal Garden Patio & Container Plants
Pests: May be attacked by glasshouse whitefly and glasshouse red spider mite

Genus: Canna are rhizomatous herbaceous perennials with erect stems bearing ovate leaves, with showy flowers with showy petal-like staminodes and small, coloured petals and sepals, borne in racemes or panicles in summer and autumn
Cultivation: Needs a sheltered, warm site and plenty of watering. In autumn, rhizomes can be lifted and stored in a frost-free place or, in mild gardens, left in the ground covered with dry mulch. See canna cultivation
Propagation: Propagate by seed or by division
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds City & Courtyard Gardens Coastal Cottage & Informal Garden Patio & Container Plants Architectural
Pruning: Leave to die back in autumn
Pests: Caterpillars, glasshouse red spider mite and aphids may be a problem
Diseases: May be affected by canna viruses

Genus: Cantua are evergreen small shrubs or trees with arching or scrambling branches and showy, terminal corymbs of narrowly tubular flowers with five spreading lobes, in a range of colours
Cultivation: Grow under glass in loam-based compost in full light. Plants may be stood outdoors for the summer. In frost-free areas grow in a warm, sheltered position in full sun. The long, flexible stems will need support
Propagation: Propagate by seed sown in heat in spring, or by semi-ripe cuttings in summer
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Wall-side Borders City & Courtyard Gardens Patio & Container Plants Mediterranean Climate Plants
Pests: Glasshouse red spider mite and glasshouse whitefly may be a problem

Genus: Caragana are deciduous, usually spiny shrubs with pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered yellow, occasionally white or pink flowers, followed by brown pods
Cultivation: Grow in well-drained soil in full sun. Useful as a windbreak
Propagation: Propagate by seed, or by softwood cuttings
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Drought Resistant Flower borders and beds Hedging & Screens Low Maintenance City & Courtyard Gardens Gravel Garden

Genus: Cardamine are herbaceous perennials with simple, palmately or pinnately divided leaves and short racemes of 4-petalled white, yellow, pink or purplish flowers in spring or summer
Cultivation: Grow in moist, humus-rich soil in full or partial shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed, bulbils or division
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden Wildlife Gardens
Pests: Can get aphids and flea beetles

Cultivation: Grow in moist, humus-rich soil in full or partial shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed or division
SuggestedPlantingLocation: Flower borders and beds Cottage & Informal Garden
Pests: Can get aphids and flea beetles

Genus: Cardamine are herbaceous perennials with simple, palmately or pinnately divided leaves and short racemes of 4-petalled white, yellow, pink or purplish flowers in spring or summer
Cultivation: Grow in moist, humus-rich soil in full or partial shade
Propagation: Propagate by seed or division
